holyDays.name: Nyepi (Balinese New Year)
holyDays.description: The Day of Silence marking the Balinese New Year. A day of self-reflection, fasting, and meditation.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Nyepi is the most important day in the Balinese Hindu calendar. It marks the beginning of the Saka New Year and is observed with complete silence, no lights, no work, and no travel. The day is dedicated to meditation and self-reflection.

holyDays.name: Galungan
holyDays.description: Three-day celebration: Penampahan Galungan (preparation), Galungan (main day), and Manis Galungan (sweet day).
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Galungan is a three-day celebration of the victory of dharma over adharma. Day 1 (Penampahan): preparation and offerings. Day 2 (Galungan): main celebration with ancestral spirits returning. Day 3 (Manis Galungan): visiting family and friends. Occurs every 210 days in the Pawukon calendar.

holyDays.name: Kuningan
holyDays.description: The day when ancestral spirits return to heaven, marking the end of Galungan celebrations.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Kuningan occurs 10 days after Galungan and marks the day when ancestral spirits ascend back to heaven. Special yellow rice offerings (nasi kuning) are prepared. It is a day of gratitude and farewell to the visiting spirits.

holyDays.name: Saraswati
holyDays.description: Day dedicated to Dewi Saraswati, goddess of knowledge, wisdom, and learning.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Saraswati Day honors the goddess of knowledge and learning. Books, manuscripts, and educational materials are blessed. Students and scholars make special offerings and refrain from reading on this day, resuming studies the following day.

holyDays.name: Pagerwesi
holyDays.description: Day to strengthen spiritual defenses and fortify one's faith.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Pagerwesi means 'iron fence' and symbolizes building spiritual protection. It is a day for meditation, prayer, and strengthening one's commitment to dharma. Special offerings are made to seek divine protection.

holyDays.name: Siwaratri
holyDays.description: Night dedicated to Lord Shiva, observed with meditation and prayer throughout the night.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Siwaratri is the holiest night of the year, dedicated to Lord Shiva. Devotees stay awake all night in meditation and prayer at temples. It is believed that sincere worship on this night brings liberation from the cycle of rebirth.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Landep
holyDays.description: Day to honor and bless metal objects, tools, and vehicles.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Landep is dedicated to Sang Hyang Pasupati, the god of metal and sharp objects. People make offerings to their tools, weapons, vehicles, and electronic devices, asking for their proper function and safety.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Wariga (Tumpek Uduh)
holyDays.description: Day to honor and bless plants and trees.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Wariga (also called Tumpek Uduh or Tumpek Bubuh) is dedicated to Sang Hyang Sangkara, the god of plants. Offerings are made to trees and plants, especially those that bear fruit, asking for abundant harvests.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Kandang
holyDays.description: Day to honor and bless animals and livestock.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Kandang is dedicated to Sang Hyang Rare Angon, the god of animals. Offerings are made to livestock, pets, and all animals, expressing gratitude for their service and asking for their health and well-being.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Wayang
holyDays.description: Day to honor and bless children and the art of wayang (shadow puppetry).
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Wayang is dedicated to Sang Hyang Iswara and honors children and the art of wayang. Special ceremonies are held for children, and wayang performances are conducted. It celebrates the creative arts and human creativity.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Krulut
holyDays.description: Day to honor and bless musical instruments and gamelan.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Krulut is dedicated to Sang Hyang Iswara and honors all musical instruments, especially gamelan. Musicians make offerings to their instruments, asking for harmony and beautiful sounds in their performances.

holyDays.name: Tumpek Uduh
holyDays.description: Alternative name for Tumpek Wariga - day to bless plants.
holyDays.culturalSignificance: Tumpek Uduh (also known as Pengatag) is another occasion to honor plants and trees. It is similar to Tumpek Wariga and emphasizes the importance of nature and agriculture in Balinese life.
